thread.title: Bank of England interest rate rises - this is what it means for your mortgage and savings

author: Hannah Graham
title: Bank of England interest rate rises - this is what it means for your mortgage and savings
text:
2% £161.69
That said, the likelihood of a continuous rise could be significantly affected by Brexit, with the UK’s post-Europe future continuing to be shrouded with uncertainty.
Bank of England Governor Mark Carney had suggested the rise could be on the way as the economy continued to pick up from a tricky patch earlier this year, partly as a result of the extreme bad weather.
At present, the Bank’s monetary policy committee judges that the economy can withstand the higher rate - but it’s entirely possible that could change, depending on the outcome of negotiations. Read More Savings
A rate rise is generally bad news for borrowers and good news for savers.
According to the BBC, the average easy-access savings account is currently paying 0.35% in annual interest. With rates so low, it’s unlikely rises will be huge.
